Florida Man visits local bottle shop for beer tasting Skip to content Download Apps Newsletter Tell Us Something Good Be Our Guest Meet the Team Advertise with Us Submit Photos and Videos Watch Live Video News First Alert Weather Sports Features Hurricane HQ Telemundo Contact Us Community InvestigateTV Home Watch Live News Gainesville Ocala Lake City State National Crime Politics Education Health Good News Sponsored First Alert Weather Hurricane HQ 24/7 Live Weather Radar Weather Maps Forecast Graphics Tropics Graphics First Alert Explained Weather 101 Sports Florida Gators High School Scholar Athlete Russell Report TV20 Coaches Spotlight Junior College Chomp List Submit Your Sports Photos Español Contact Us News Tips Meet the Team Download Our Apps Advertise Employment Advertise Features Bright Futures One Class at a Time Hometown Heroes Paige's Kitchen Tech Tuesday FL Man Adventures Adopt A Pet Wildlife Wednesday Fitness Community Community Calendar Contests TV20 Newsletter Sign-Up Submit Photos and Videos Tell Us Something Good Programming Schedule Zeam - News Streams Gray DC Bureau NextGen TV Zeam - News Streams InvestigateTV Watching Your Wallet Be Our Guest Sky20 Drone Your Local Chamber Your Local Experts HealthCARES Watch ABC Online PowerNation Circle Country Digital Marketing Florida Man visits local bottle shop for beer tasting Crafty Bastards Restaurant and Bottle Shop have been serving up delicious craft beer for over a decade. By WCJB Staff Published : Feb. 6, 2025 at 5:52 PM EST Email This Link Share on Facebook Share on X (formerly Twitter) Share on Pinterest Share on LinkedIn GAINESVILLE, Fla. (WCJB) - On this installment of Florida man adventures we are here in Gainesville at Crafty Bastards Bottle Shoppe where we will be tasting some free beer. Let’s check it out. Crafty Bastards Restaurant and Bottle Shop have been serving up delicious craft beer for over a decade. They pride themselves on having a massive selection with thousands of beers and wines to choose from. “We have many different varieties of beer from around the world. Imports, domestics, we sell everything individually so you can pick and choose from what we have available here, one beer at a time, build your own six pack or so,” said Jeffery Brunson, manager at Crafty’s. Once a week Crafty’s Bottle Shoppe brings in beer, that’s my favorite flavor: free! “Every Thursday from 6 to 8 p.m. we offer a free beer tasting, different breweries battling to get over here and pour beer for everybody,” said Brunson These tastings are a great way to learn about craft beer and fine tune your personal taste. Exploring different types of beer is the name of the game. “If we have a brewery showing up, what we will have is their variety of beer available from the distributor. Which will consist of different styles of beer. When we are hosting, we will pick a specific style, then pick an assortment of beers from that style for you to get a feeling of what’s going on there,” said Brunson Every week dozens of people come and study these premium suds, with their taste buds. So, in the spirit of academia, you should too. For more information on Crafty Bastards Bottle Shoppe click here , for TV20 News, I’m Adam Pittman, and this has been Florida Man Adventures. RELATED: Florida Man revs his engine at All-Tech Raceway in Lake City Click here to subscribe to our newsletter. Copyright 2025 WCJB. All rights reserved. Get Help. Disaster Resources Emergency Food & Shelter Tri-County Disaster Recovery Community Investments Get Involved Give Back Donate Planned Giving Partner Small Business United Volunteer News Events Tuxedo T-shirt Gala Holiday Luncheon Light Up Tioga Small Business Partner - Crafty Bastards Betty Brunson, Owner of Crafty Bastards 1. Tell us about your business and your business philosophy: It started with a very crafty idea.  “Open a pub!” they said. “It will be fun!” they said. That was an understatement! When we opened our pub, The Crafty Bastards, in 2015, people often asked us, “What made you retire to do this?”  Our answer was simple: It’s what we’ve always wanted to do! We felt the northwest area of Gainesville needed a local, convenient, quality craft beer pub that included a small selection of fresh, made to order, food to complement the beverages.  Three years later, The Crafty Bastards is known as a full-service restaurant and pub that provides a family-friendly and fun environment. And, we even added a craft beer bottle shop right next door last year! Our business philosophy is to achieve excellence in all we do, customer service, food preparation, cleanliness, etc. And we know to accomplish that, we need to support our team in becoming the best they can be both professionally and personally. We are also committed to supporting other local businesses, local breweries, local produce etc.  We partner with Gainesville Harley-Davidson’s Chili Cook-off. We pay the winner of the cook-off $500 to use their chili recipe for one year in the restaurant. 2. Why are you passionate about your commitment to United Way’s Community Investment Fund? I started my career at Publix and had the opportunity to learn about United Way and donate through payroll deduction. As a small business owner, I am committed to supporting the community, but lack the time to volunteer. By donating to United Way, I know I am assisting local initiatives that work to help make our community stronger. 3. What is something interesting or surprising that most people don’t know about you? I own and ride a Harley Davidson motorcycle. 4. What would your older self tell your younger self? So many things, but then again, I wouldn’t be who I am today without the challenges and blessing I have received in the past.  I am very grateful for the journey my life has given me. 5. Favorite quote: “Don’t lower your standards because others won’t raise theirs.” Small businesses play a critical role in maintaining a thriving local economy. They are no less important to the success of United Way, as we endeavor to improve lives through our work in education, health and financial stability. Our Small Business Partners are an important, growing family of donors, who are vital to helping us meet the needs of our community. To learn more about how you and your business can support United Way, contact Dana Clayton at dclayton@unitedwayncfl.org or (352) 333-0846 . Click here for more Small Business Spotlights. Click here for our Small Business Spotlight directory. Improving lives by mobilizing the caring power of communities. Crafty Bastard Brewery closes South Knoxville taproom at Baker Creek News Sports Business Go Knoxville Shopper News Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals DINING Under a new structure, Crafty Bastard Brewery closes South Knoxville taproom. What's next? Joanna Hayes Knoxville News Sentinel Correction: A previous version of this report misstated Crafty Bastard Brewery founder Aaron McClain's role under restructured ownership. Majority owner Scott Sherrill will take over operations in a public-facing role for the business. McClain will remain as a minority owner. Crafty Bastard Brewery has closed its taproom at Baker Creek Bottoms, one of three taprooms for one of Knoxville's original craft breweries, whose flagship Emory Place location has been serving customers since 2015. It was fall 2023 when Crafty Bastard opened this third location inside a former South Knoxville church, which has been undergoing redevelopment since 2017 to create a mixed-use community of shops and restaurants tied to adjacent Baker Creek Preserve bike trails. Crafty Bastard founder Aaron McClain told Knox News just before opening that branching out with multiple locations was never part of his original plans. "I thought we were starting just a small little grungy warehouse where we were going to make some cool beers and make enough money to pay my bills, hopefully," he said in 2023. But the brewery has experienced major changes since then, namely that McClain is no longer ownership's face of the brewery. Majority owner Scott Sherrill has taken over operations, which included shutting down the South Knoxville branch. Looking for a free mini puzzle? Play the USA TODAY Quick Cross now. "Aaron has always been a non-majority owner, for as long as I have been involved. Aaron is no longer involved in any Crafty operations or decision," Sherrill told Knox News via text. "There's no doubt as to Aaron's creative talents - if there is a way to one day harness those talents in a limited capacity, we both remain open to that. However, we have no plans to that effect at the moment." Sherrill did not disclose what exactly led to the closure − only that the decision allows Crafty Bastard to focus "on what has made our customers happiest: providing our fans and community with the best beer in Knoxville," he said, noting the decision was made at the end of 2024. The taproom had church pews inside for seating. While no beer was made on site, Crafty Bastard maintained 14 rotating taps and offered to-go beer. It also had food made exclusively for the brewery by neighboring 71 South, the restaurant anchor of the church property. "The thing I do want to say is just how much this space has been rehabilitated. This was not a church. The church is the people," McClain previously told Knox News. "This building has been left to rot for 30 years and was this close to being unrecoverable." With space to seat 70 people inside the taproom, along with overflow seating and outdoor spaces that could accommodate 65 more, McClain saw the space becoming a gathering place for South Knoxville residents. These 4 local breweries are 2025 World Beer Cup winners. See which brews came out on top First big event set for Smokies stadium brings loads of beer to the ballpark: Cheers, Xul! Local 'Steel Arm' lager at Smokies stadium to honor Negro-League Giants of 1920s Knoxville More PB&J Mixtape? Full Stocking: A new Alliance beer is part of a century-old Knoxville holiday tradition Tip your server and enjoy a Smokies stadium tip to save money on the best drinks we tried Crafty Bastard's flagship location at 6 Emory Place and its West Knoxville location at 9937 Kingston Pike remain open. "In 2025, we will be continuing to release new, unique beers and reinvesting in our customer experience at our existing locations downtown and West," Sherrill said. Joanna Hayes is the restaurant and retail reporter. Email: joanna.hayes@knoxnews.com . Support strong local journalism by subscribing at subscribe.knoxnews.com.
